raw_text:
Briton wins short film Oscar
 
 Three of the five nominees in the live-action short film category at this year's Oscars were British. For Andrea Arnold, who won the category, Ashvin Kumar and Gary McKendry the past month has thrust them from relative obscurity into the limelight.
 
 Arnold's gritty drama Wasp is about a single mother living on the breadline, while Kumar's Little Terrorist follows a young Pakistani Muslim boy, who gets stuck on the wrong side of the heavily armed Indian border. McKendry's entry, Everything In This Country Must, forces British soldiers and Catholics to challenge their relationship during the troubles in Northern Ireland. Last week, the trio attended an official screening of all the nominated short films at the Academy's headquarters in Beverly Hills. "I felt so privileged to have a thousand people watching my film on the biggest screen I've ever seen," says Arnold.
 
 Set in her native Dartford, Wasp tells the story of a young mum, who, unable to find a babysitter, leaves her four young daughters outside a pub while she's on a date. The image that sparked the film was that of a wasp crawling into a baby's mouth. "The other nominees said they made their films for this reason or that - they had something to say. But I just start with an image I can't shake off, work outwards from that and see what comes out," she explains.
 
 Since she presented children's TV shows Number 73 and Motormouth in the 1980s, Arnold has kept a low profile and is having trouble adapting to this sudden onslaught of attention. "I'm not interested in the publicity. It's not my personality. I'm overwhelmed by all the fuss," she said.
 
 "It's all a bit like a beauty contest - all the films are great and so different. "But even though my film has won 30 awards worldwide (including one at Sundance last month), I'd still be proud of it - even if it hadn't won any." Asked what the nomination means to her, Arnold says she feels "flattered and honoured". "We've all been overwhelmed by the response and can't get it in perspective yet. I'm still reeling."
 
 And she won't commit to an opinion of Hollywood yet. "I'm just in the middle of it, living moment to moment, day to day." But despite her reservations about the Academy Awards and the media frenzy that surrounds it, she accepts that it has opened doors for her. "People will definitely listen to what I want to do now, and the phone didn't stop ringing for a week after I got nominated." As for the future, Arnold firmly believes that you often get a stronger vision of the world with short films. "You're left more to your own devices, without people interfering as much." That said, she is currently working on a feature film with Dogville and Dancer In The Dark director Lars Von Trier.
llama3.2:1b: Andrea Arnold wins Oscar for live-action short film Wasp, an animated story about a single mother living on the breadline.
Three British nominees are Ashvin Kumar's Little Terrorist, Gary McKendry's Everything In This Country Must, and Andrea Arnold's Wasp.
Arnold's film was nominated due to its use of an image that sparked discussion in the industry - a baby with a wasp crawling into their mouth.
llama3.2:3b: Briton Andrea Arnold wins live-action short film Oscar for Wasp, a gritty drama about a single mother living on the breadline.
Other British nominees include Ashvin Kumar's Little Terrorist and Gary McKendry's Everything In This Country Must.
Arnold keeps a low profile despite sudden attention, calling her film-making style "not interested in the publicity."
She accepts the Oscar nomination as an honor and believes it has opened doors for future projects, including a feature film with Lars Von Trier.
gemma2:2b: Andrea Arnold won the live-action short film Oscar for her gritty drama "Wasp".
The film focuses on a single mother's struggle and was praised by critics for its raw and compelling depiction of life's challenges.
Arnold's win has catapulted her to international prominence, bringing attention to both her work and the unique power of short films.
Despite her unexpected rise, Arnold maintains a humble stance, finding solace in the process of filmmaking itself and accepting the opportunities that come with recognition.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A British filmmaker won the Academy Award for Best Short Film for her drama "Wasp" about a single mother living on the streets who works to feed her four children outside their pub.
The Academy said she was in the limelight, but Arnold admitted it wasn't easy.
She felt so privileged that she attended an official screening of all the nominated short films and spoke candidly about the award.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Three British nominees for this year's Oscars in the live-action short film category were selected by Andrea Arnold, Ashvin Kumar, and Gary McKendry: Wasp (Gritty drama about a single mother), Little Terrorist (Pakistani Muslim boy caught on Indian border), and Everything In This Country Must.
qwen2.5:3b: Briton Andrea Arnold wins Oscar for her gritty drama Wasp about a single mother living on the breadline.
Her film was one of three British nominees in the live-action short film category, which also included Little Terrorist by Ashvin Kumar and Everything in This Country Must by Gary McKendry.
Since winning, Arnold has struggled with sudden attention but feels honored and flattered.
Prior to this recognition, she had kept a low profile in her native Dartford, where she once presented children's TV shows.
Although skeptical about Hollywood’s impact initially, she acknowledges it opened doors for her as media attention continued weeks after the nomination.
Arnold believes short films offer a clearer vision of the world and has begun work on a feature film with Lars von Trier.
opencoder:1.5b: "Briton wins short film Oscar for three nominees in this year's Oscars.
Andrea Arnold has won the category for 3 months and moved from obscurity to the limelight, thanks to the films she presented: Wasp, Little Terrorist, and Everything In This Country Must."
smollm:1.7b: The three British nominees in the live-action short film category at this year's Oscars were Andrea Arnold, Ashvin Kumar, and Gary McKendry.
For Andrea Arnold, who won the category, Ashvin Kumar and Gary McKendry the past month has thrust them from relative obscurity into the limelight.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Arnada Arnold won an Oscar for a gritty drama about a single mother facing childlessness.
The trio, including her, presented their work in response to Academy attention.
Arnold is proud of her win and will discuss the future, accepting an award that highlights short films' power to illuminate without much interference.
tinyllama:1.1b: After receiving nominations in the live-action short film category at this year's Academy Awards, three British filmmakers won a prestigious award for their works: Andrea Arnold, Ashvin Kuhar, and Gary McKendry.
The trio attended an official screening of all five nominated films at the Academy's headquarter in Beverly Hills to experience their emotions from their success.
Despite their initial reservation about the Academy Awards, they accepted that it had opened doors for them, and that it has opened the door for them to experiment with longer works.
While still reeling from their nominations, Arnold emphasizes that she will listen to the opinions of Hollywood while living moment by moment and day by day.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In the wake of the Oscars short film nominations announced earlier this month, the British Academy (BAFTA) has announced that three of its five nominees in the live-action short film category were from the United Kingdom.

Among these is director Andrea Arnold's Wasp, which centers on a single mother struggling to make ends meet amidst the strained relationship between her daughters and British soldiers stationed in Northern Ireland.
Wasp was nominated for Best Short Film at the Academy Awards, but it was not one of the five films shortlisted for the Best Picture nomination.
Despite this setback, Wasp remains an impressive film that managed to capture the hearts and minds of audiences around the world.
In another notable nomination, Kumar's Little Terrorist also made the shortlist with director Gary McKendry, who won for his previous entry Little Terrorist earlier this year.
Little Terrorist follows a young Pakistani Muslim boy forced to navigate the challenges of life on the wrong side of the heavily armed Indian border.
Arnold's Little Terrorist and Everything In This Country Must were also nominated in the same category, demonstrating the competitive nature of this year's short film submissions.
The other nominees in the category are directed by Ashvin Kumar and Gary McKendry, who previously won for their work on Little Terrorist.

The three British-based directors have received significant attention for pushing the boundaries of cinema with their unique storytelling methods, including using non-professional actors and relying heavily on real footage.
Despite the success of these films, Arnold remains humble and is not interested in the pressure associated with winning an Academy Award or the world stage.
She believes that she has a stronger vision for her work and is currently working on a feature film with Dancer In The Dark director Lars Von Trier, who directed Wasp and Little Terrorist.
Despite their accolades, all three British-based directors have faced challenges in gaining recognition and adapting to the complexities of the entertainment industry.
Despite these obstacles, it has undoubtedly opened doors for them, allowing them to continue creating powerful films that challenge conventional notions of storytelling.

Arnold's film, about a single mother struggling to make ends meet, sparked the project as she watched a wasp crawl into a baby's mouth.
The other nominees said they made their films for different reasons, but Arnold started with an image she couldn't shake off and worked outwards from there.
Since her TV shows in the 1990s, she has kept a low profile and is struggling to adapt to the sudden attention, feeling overwhelmed by all the fuss.
Despite her reservations about Hollywood and the Academy Awards, she sees it as an opportunity to have people listen to what she wants to do.
She's also currently working on a feature film with Dogville and Dancer In The Dark director Lars Von Trier.

Arnold's film tells the story of a young mother who leaves her children outside a pub while on a date, and the image that sparked the film was a wasp crawling into a baby's mouth.
Despite being an unknown quantity in the industry, Arnold is having trouble adapting to the sudden attention, saying she's "flattered and honoured" to have won 30 awards worldwide.

Despite her reservations about Hollywood, she is honored by the recognition and is now working on a feature film with director Lars Von Trier.

Despite her reservations, she believes that winning opened doors for future projects, with people more likely to listen to what she wants to do next.
As for the present, Arnold still isn "reeling" from the recent events and will remain in the moment throughout this journey.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Andrea Arnold, a British filmmaker, won the live-action short film category at this year's Oscars for her gritty drama "Wasp," which depicts a struggling single mother's plight.

Co-nominees Ashvin Kumar ("Little Terrorist") and Gary McKendry ("Everything In This Country Must") also gained recognition, their films highlighting diverse themes: Pakistani boy caught at an unguarded border and the complexities of Northern Irish soldiers' relationships during the Troubles.
Attending the official screening of all nominated shorts in Beverly Hills was a once-in-a-lifetime experience for Arnold, whose career has largely focused on children's TV shows since the 1980s.
Despite her initial reluctance to publicity and media attention, she feels flattered by the recognition, with "Wasp" winning 30 awards worldwide.
Although still wary of Hollywood, Arnold acknowledges that nomination has opened doors for her projects, including a collaboration with Lars Von Trier on a feature film.
